name: Boeing 777-300
description: The Boeing 777-300 is the stretched variant of the original 777, extended by 10.1 meters over the 777-200 to become one of the longest commercial aircraft ever built at 73.9 meters. First delivered in 1998, it was designed to replace aging Boeing 747-100 and 747-200 aircraft on high-density routes. The 777-300 seats up to 550 passengers in a single-class configuration or approximately 370 in a typical three-class layout.

zones.name: Cockpit
zones.description: The 777-300 flight deck is identical to the 777-200, with the same fly-by-wire glass cockpit and six LCD displays. Pilots require the same type rating for both variants.

zones.name: Forward Galley
zones.description: The forward galley serving first and business class on the stretched fuselage.

zones.name: Forward Lavatory
zones.description: Forward lavatories near the premium class cabin.

zones.name: Forward Vestibule
zones.description: The forward entry vestibule at door 1L/1R for primary passenger boarding.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: The left seat section of the forward cabin, housing first and business class window and aisle seats on the port side. The stretched fuselage allows generous premium cabin space.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the forward cabin, one of the twin aisles running through the wide-body 777-300. Passengers and crew use this aisle to move between the forward vestibule and mid cabin.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: The center seat section of the forward cabin between the twin aisles. In first class this may be a 2-abreast configuration; in business class typically 3-abreast with direct aisle access.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the forward cabin, the starboard twin aisle providing a second path through the premium cabin for improved passenger flow.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: The right seat section of the forward cabin on the starboard side, mirroring the left seat section with first and business class seating.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: The left seat section of the mid cabin, providing the bulk of the economy class seating on the port side. The 10.1m fuselage stretch adds significantly more rows here compared to the 777-200.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the expansive mid cabin. This long aisle stretches 45 grid units through the largest cabin section of the 777-300, serving the bulk of economy passengers.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: The center seat section of the mid cabin between the twin aisles. Typically configured as 3 or 4 abreast in economy class, these center seats make up a large portion of the 777-300's high-density capacity.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the mid cabin, the starboard twin aisle through the largest cabin section. Twin aisles are essential for efficient meal service and passenger movement in this extended section.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: The right seat section of the mid cabin on the starboard side, mirroring the left with economy class seating. Window seats offer views of the wing and conventional wingtips.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: The left seat section of the aft cabin, extended by the fuselage stretch. The 777-300 can seat up to 550 passengers in a high-density single-class configuration.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the aft cabin, continuing the port-side twin aisle from the mid cabin toward the aft vestibule and galley.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: The center seat section of the aft cabin between the twin aisles. Economy class seats here are close to the aft galley and lavatories. The tail skid below protects the stretched fuselage during rotation.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the aft cabin, the starboard twin aisle connecting to the aft vestibule.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: The right seat section of the aft cabin on the starboard side. Last rows are nearest the aft galley, providing quick service but also more galley noise.

zones.name: Aft Vestibule
zones.description: The aft entry vestibule. The stretched fuselage has additional door pairs for evacuation compliance.

zones.name: Aft Galley
zones.description: The aft galley scaled up to serve the 777-300's higher passenger capacity.

zones.name: Aft Lavatory
zones.description: Multiple aft lavatories serving the large economy cabin. More units are installed than on the 777-200 due to higher passenger counts.

zones.name: Forward Cargo Hold
zones.description: The forward lower-deck cargo hold beneath the forward cabin. The stretched fuselage provides increased cargo volume, accommodating LD3 containers side by side in the wide-body lower lobe.

zones.name: Aft Cargo Hold
zones.description: The aft lower-deck cargo hold beneath the mid and aft cabins. Significantly larger than on the 777-200 due to the fuselage stretch, this hold handles the bulk of containerized freight.

zones.name: Bulk Cargo Hold
zones.description: The bulk cargo compartment in the aft fuselage for loose-loaded baggage and small freight items that do not require containerization.

zones.name: Cargo Access
zones.description: The cargo access area connecting the passenger deck to the lower cargo holds via a narrow passage near the nose gear bay. Used by ground crew for cargo operations.

zones.name: Nose
zones.description: The nose section with weather radar, identical to the 777-200.

zones.name: Forward Fuselage
zones.description: The forward lower fuselage with the forward cargo hold, providing increased cargo volume due to the stretched fuselage.

zones.name: Mid Fuselage
zones.description: The center lower fuselage with wing box and center fuel tank. The wing position remains the same relative to the aircraft's center of gravity.

zones.name: Aft Fuselage
zones.description: The aft lower fuselage with the extended aft cargo hold, providing significantly more cargo volume than the 777-200.

zones.name: Tail
zones.description: The tail section. The 777-300 features a semi-levered main gear and a tail skid to protect the longer fuselage from tail strikes during rotation.

zones.name: Left Wing
zones.description: The port wing, identical to the 777-200 with conventional wingtips. Fuel capacity is adequate for the 777-300's shorter range mission profile.

zones.name: Right Wing
zones.description: The starboard wing, identical to the port wing configuration.

zones.name: Left Engine
zones.description: The left engine, either GE90-115B or Rolls-Royce Trent 892. The GE90-115B produces 115,300 lbs of thrust for the heavier stretched variant.

zones.name: Right Engine
zones.description: The right engine, matching the left engine selection.

zones.name: Left Main Gear
zones.description: The left six-wheel bogie main gear with a semi-levered design that shortens the gear for a lower cabin floor height during ground operations.

zones.name: Right Main Gear
zones.description: The right six-wheel bogie main gear with semi-levered design.

zones.name: Nose Gear
zones.description: The steerable nose gear, identical to the 777-200.

zones.name: Vertical Stabilizer
zones.description: The vertical stabilizer providing directional stability for the longer fuselage.

zones.name: Horizontal Stabilizer
zones.description: The trimmable horizontal stabilizer with elevators, providing pitch authority for the stretched airframe.

zones.name: APU
zones.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU providing ground power for the larger aircraft.

components.name: Captain's Control Column
components.description: The captain's fly-by-wire control column, identical to the 777-200.
components.interactionText: Grasp the captain's yoke. The 777-300 shares the same type rating as the 777-200.

components.name: First Officer's Control Column
components.description: The first officer's fly-by-wire control column.
components.interactionText: The first officer's yoke provides independent fly-by-wire authority.

components.name: Throttle Quadrant
components.description: Twin thrust levers for the GE90-115B or Trent 892 engines.
components.interactionText: Command the high-thrust engines needed to move the stretched fuselage at maximum takeoff weight.

components.name: Rudder Pedals
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder pedals with speed-dependent authority.
components.interactionText: Rudder authority is especially important on the longer fuselage for crosswind operations.

components.name: Primary Flight Display (PFD)
components.description: Large-format PFD identical to the 777-200.
components.interactionText: The PFD shows attitude, speeds, altitude, and flight modes.

components.name: Navigation Display (ND)
components.description: Navigation display for route and traffic management on high-density routes.
components.interactionText: View route, terrain, traffic, and weather on the navigation display.

components.name: Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System
components.description: EICAS monitoring both engines and all aircraft systems on the stretched variant.
components.interactionText: Monitor engine parameters and system status. The tail camera display is especially useful for this long aircraft.

components.name: Overhead Panel
components.description: Systems control panel identical to the 777-200.
components.interactionText: The overhead panel controls are shared across 777 variants due to the common type rating.

components.name: Mode Control Panel (MCP)
components.description: Autopilot interface for managing flight profiles on regional and medium-haul routes.
components.interactionText: Set speed, heading, altitude targets for the autopilot on high-density routes.

components.name: Flight Management Computer (FMC)
components.description: Triple-redundant FMC for flight planning on the 777-300's regional and medium-haul route network.
components.interactionText: Program routes on the FMC. The 777-300 typically operates on shorter routes than the ER and LR variants.

components.name: Forward Left Entry Door (1L)
components.description: The main wide-body boarding door. The stretched fuselage has five door pairs to meet evacuation requirements for up to 550 passengers.
components.interactionText: The forward door is one of five door pairs needed for emergency evacuation of up to 550 passengers.

components.name: Aft Left Entry Door (5L)
components.description: The aft left entry door. Additional door pairs are required on the stretched fuselage for certification.
components.interactionText: The stretched fuselage requires additional exit doors compared to the 777-200 for evacuation compliance.

components.name: Forward Galley Unit
components.description: The premium class forward galley serving first and business class passengers.
components.interactionText: The forward galley supports premium meal service for the forward cabin.

components.name: Aft Galley Unit
components.description: The aft economy galley, scaled up for the 777-300's higher passenger capacity of up to 550.
components.interactionText: The enlarged aft galley serves up to 400 economy passengers with multiple service carts.

components.name: Overhead Storage Bins
components.description: Wide-body overhead bins spanning the extended cabin length for the larger passenger count.
components.interactionText: Three rows of overhead bins accommodate carry-on luggage for up to 550 passengers.

components.name: Row 1 First Class Seats
components.description: First class seats in the forward cabin of the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: First class suites on the 777-300 benefit from the spacious wide-body cabin width.

components.name: Forward Cabin Business Class Seats
components.description: Business class seats in the forward cabin of the stretched 777-300. The longer fuselage allows for a larger premium cabin. Seats are typically configured in a 2-3-2 layout with lie-flat capability on long-haul configured aircraft.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin business class seat on the stretched 777-300. The extended fuselage provides a spacious premium cabin. Check the entertainment screen, power outlet, and adjustable seat controls.

components.name: Mid Cabin Front Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the forward part of the 777-300's expansive mid cabin. The stretched fuselage creates one of the longest economy cabins in commercial aviation. Seats are in a 3-3-3 or 3-4-3 configuration depending on the airline. This section often begins premium economy on some carriers.
components.interactionText: Sit in the front of the mid cabin economy section. The 777-300's stretched fuselage means this mid section is enormous. Some airlines place premium economy here with extra legroom and wider seats.

components.name: Mid Cabin Rear Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the rear portion of the mid cabin. The 777-300's mid cabin spans 45 grid units, the largest of any 777 variant. Emergency exits in the mid section divide the cabin and provide extra legroom in adjacent rows.
components.interactionText: Sit in the rear of the mid cabin. You are deep in the middle of this stretched aircraft. The mid-cabin emergency exits are nearby, with illuminated exit signs above. Check the seatback screen and overhead bin.

components.name: Aft Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the aft cabin of the 777-300. The stretched fuselage adds significant seating capacity in the rear. In high-density configuration, the 777-300 can seat up to 550 passengers. Aft seats are closest to the rear galleys and lavatories. The tail skid below protects against tail strikes during takeoff rotation.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft cabin seat on the stretched 777-300. You are near the back of one of the longest commercial aircraft in service. The rear galley and lavatories are just behind. The tail skid below protects this long fuselage during rotation.

components.name: Passenger Cabin Window
components.description: Standard 777 cabin windows along the extended fuselage. The 777-300 has more windows than the 777-200 due to its stretched length.
components.interactionText: Look through the 777 cabin window. The stretched fuselage means more window seats are available.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins running along the left side of the forward cabin above the port-side window seats.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the forward cabin. These bins serve first and business class passengers on the port side.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins running along the right side of the forward cabin above the starboard-side window seats.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the forward cabin. Premium cabin bins are often larger to accommodate suit bags and coats.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the left side of the expansive mid cabin, spanning the longest cabin section of the 777-300.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the mid cabin. The extended mid section has more bin space than any other 777 variant.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the right side of the mid cabin on the starboard side.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the mid cabin. Bin space fills quickly on high-density 777-300 flights with up to 550 passengers.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the left side of the aft cabin in the rear section of the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the aft cabin. Rear bins sometimes have more space available as forward bins fill first during boarding.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the right side of the aft cabin on the starboard side.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the aft cabin. The 777-300's stretched fuselage provides bin storage for hundreds of carry-on bags.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the forward cabin, offering views from the premium class section.
components.interactionText: Look through the left window in the forward cabin. From first or business class, you can see the airport terminal during boarding or the clouds at cruise altitude.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the forward cabin on the starboard side.
components.interactionText: Look through the right window in the forward premium cabin. The 777's windows are among the largest in commercial aviation at 15 inches tall.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the mid cabin, positioned over the wing area with views of the port engine and wing.
components.interactionText: Look through the left window in the mid cabin. You can see the port wing, engine nacelle, and conventional wingtip from this position.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the mid cabin with views of the starboard wing and engine.
components.interactionText: Look through the right window over the wing. You can see the starboard engine and wing flex during turbulence from this seat.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the aft cabin, behind the wing trailing edge.
components.interactionText: Look through the left window in the aft cabin. Behind the wing, you have a clear view of the flaps deploying during approach.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the aft cabin on the starboard side.
components.interactionText: Look through the right aft window. From this far back on the stretched fuselage, the wing trailing edge and flap tracks are visible during landing configuration.

components.name: Forward Exit Row Left Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the left side of the forward cabin near the over-wing emergency exit. Provides extra legroom due to exit door clearance requirements.
components.interactionText: Sit in the forward exit row seat on the left. Extra legroom here comes with the responsibility to assist in an emergency. The exit door mechanism is within reach.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the right side of the forward cabin in business class, offering views through the large 777 windows.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin window seat on the starboard side. Business class window seats on the 777-300 offer privacy and excellent views.

components.name: Forward Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the forward cabin between the twin aisles, typical of first class honeymoon or companion seating.
components.interactionText: Sit in the center of the forward cabin between the twin aisles. In first class, center seats are often configured as companion suites.

components.name: Mid Cabin Exit Row Left Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the left side of the mid cabin at the over-wing emergency exit. The most sought-after economy seat for its generous legroom.
components.interactionText: Sit in the mid cabin exit row on the left side. This is one of the most popular economy seats for its extra legroom at the over-wing exit.

components.name: Mid Cabin Exit Row Right Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the right side of the mid cabin at the over-wing emergency exit, mirroring the left side with extra legroom.
components.interactionText: Sit in the mid cabin exit row on the right. You can see the wing and engine through the large exit window. Extra legroom makes this a premium economy seat on some airlines.

components.name: Mid Cabin Front Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the front of the mid cabin. In 3-4-3 configuration, center seats have two middle seats without direct aisle access.
components.interactionText: Sit in the center of the mid cabin front section. In high-density 3-4-3 layout, the center block has four seats between the twin aisles.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the left side of the mid cabin over the wing, offering views of the port engine and wing surfaces.
components.interactionText: Sit at the left window in the mid cabin. From here you can watch the slats and flaps deploy on the port wing during approach.

components.name: Mid Cabin Rear Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the rear of the expansive mid cabin. Deep within the longest cabin section of any 777 variant.
components.interactionText: Sit in the center of the rear mid cabin. You are in the heart of the 777-300's enormous economy section, the longest single cabin of any 777.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window Rear Seat
components.description: A window seat on the right side toward the rear of the mid cabin, behind the wing trailing edge.
components.interactionText: Sit at the right window in the rear mid cabin. Behind the wing, you have an unobstructed view of the sky and ground below.

components.name: Aft Cabin Exit Row Left Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the left side of the aft cabin near the aft emergency exit, with extra legroom.
components.interactionText: Sit in the aft cabin exit row on the left. Extra legroom and proximity to the aft exit make this a desirable economy seat.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the right side of the aft cabin, toward the rear of the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: Sit at the right window in the aft cabin. Looking back, you can see the horizontal stabilizer and the long fuselage stretching behind the wing.

components.name: Aft Cabin Last Row Center Seat
components.description: The last row center seat in the aft cabin, closest to the aft galley and lavatories. Often has limited recline due to the bulkhead behind.
components.interactionText: Sit in the very last row of the 777-300. The aft galley is directly behind. Seats here may not recline fully but you are first to be served from the rear galley.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Rear Seat
components.description: A left-side seat near the rear of the aft cabin, close to the aft lavatories and galley.
components.interactionText: Sit on the left side near the back of the aft cabin. The aft lavatories are just a few rows behind, convenient on this long aircraft.

components.name: Forward Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 unit load device containers in the forward cargo hold. The 777's wide-body lower lobe accommodates LD3 containers side by side, maximizing cargo revenue on the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: Rows of LD3 containers fill the forward cargo hold. Each container can hold about 1,600 kg of baggage or freight, loaded through the forward cargo door.

components.name: Forward Cargo Net and Barrier
components.description: Cargo nets and barriers in the forward hold securing LD3 containers and preventing load shift during flight. Essential for maintaining aircraft center of gravity.
components.interactionText: Cargo nets stretch across the forward hold, securing containers against turbulence and maneuvering loads. Proper restraint is critical for flight safety.

components.name: Forward Cargo Door Mechanism
components.description: The hydraulic cargo door mechanism for the forward lower cargo hold. The door opens outward and upward for ground loading of LD3 containers.
components.interactionText: The forward cargo door mechanism uses hydraulic actuators to open the large door. Multiple safety latches prevent in-flight opening. The door warning system is monitored on EICAS.

components.name: Aft Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 containers in the aft cargo hold, the largest cargo compartment on the 777-300. The stretched fuselage provides significantly more aft cargo volume than the 777-200.
components.interactionText: The aft cargo hold is packed with LD3 containers. The 777-300's stretched fuselage means this hold is much larger than on the 777-200, supporting high-capacity routes.

components.name: Aft Cargo Net and Barrier
components.description: Cargo nets and barriers in the aft hold securing the larger volume of containers in the stretched fuselage's extended aft compartment.
components.interactionText: Heavy-duty cargo nets secure the aft hold containers. The larger aft hold on the stretched fuselage requires additional restraint points.

components.name: Aft Cargo Door Mechanism
components.description: The hydraulic cargo door mechanism for the aft lower cargo hold, providing access to the largest cargo compartment on the 777-300.
components.interactionText: The aft cargo door opens to reveal the 777-300's spacious aft cargo hold. Ground loaders use powered conveyor systems to position LD3 containers inside.

components.name: Bulk Cargo Compartment
components.description: The bulk cargo compartment in the aft fuselage behind the aft cargo hold. Used for loose-loaded baggage, mail, and small freight items that do not fit in standard LD3 containers.
components.interactionText: The bulk cargo area holds loose baggage and small freight. Items are hand-loaded through a smaller door, separate from the main cargo doors.

components.name: Left GE90-115B Engine
components.description: The left GE90-115B or Trent 892 engine providing the thrust needed for the heavier stretched variant.
components.interactionText: The GE90-115B produces 115,300 lbs of thrust to handle the 777-300's higher maximum takeoff weight.

components.name: Right GE90-115B Engine
components.description: The right engine matching the left engine selection.
components.interactionText: Both engines provide the combined thrust needed for the 777-300's 299,370 kg MTOW.

components.name: Nose Landing Gear Assembly
components.description: The nose gear, identical to the 777-200.
components.interactionText: The nose gear steers the long fuselage during taxi operations.

components.name: Left Main Landing Gear
components.description: The left six-wheel bogie with semi-levered design. The semi-levered gear reduces the kneeling effect during braking on the longer fuselage.
components.interactionText: The semi-levered main gear design reduces nose-down pitch during braking, preventing tail strike risk on the stretched fuselage.

components.name: Right Main Landing Gear
components.description: The right six-wheel bogie with semi-levered design, identical to the left.
components.interactionText: The semi-levered gear allows higher rotation angles during takeoff without tail strike.

components.name: Left Aileron
components.description: The left fly-by-wire aileron on the port wing.
components.interactionText: The fly-by-wire aileron provides roll control for the longer aircraft.

components.name: Right Aileron
components.description: The right fly-by-wire aileron on the starboard wing.
components.interactionText: The right aileron works opposite to the left for roll control.

components.name: Left Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon on the left wing.
components.interactionText: Fowler flaps extend for takeoff and landing at the 777-300's high weights.

components.name: Right Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon on the right wing.
components.interactionText: Right flaps deploy symmetrically with the left for balanced lift augmentation.

components.name: Left Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the left wing.
components.interactionText: Full-span slats delay stall for the heavier stretched variant.

components.name: Right Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the right wing.
components.interactionText: Symmetric slat deployment for balanced lift during configuration changes.

components.name: Elevator
components.description: Fly-by-wire elevators providing pitch authority for the stretched airframe with increased moment arm.
components.interactionText: The elevator must provide adequate pitch authority for the longer fuselage. Rotation during takeoff requires careful technique to avoid tail strikes.

components.name: Rudder
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder with triple-redundant hydraulic actuators. The longer fuselage moment arm provides good directional authority.
components.interactionText: The longer fuselage provides a greater moment arm for the rudder, aiding directional control.

components.name: Wing Spoilers / Speed Brakes
components.description: Fly-by-wire spoiler panels for speed brakes, ground spoilers, and roll augmentation.
components.interactionText: Spoilers are critical for managing the descent rate of the heavier stretched aircraft.

components.name: Tail Skid
components.description: A retractable tail skid mounted on the underside of the aft fuselage to protect against tail strikes during takeoff rotation. Essential for the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: The tail skid deploys during takeoff to protect the fuselage if the pilot over-rotates. The 777-300's length makes tail strikes a concern.

components.name: Weather Radar Antenna
components.description: Weather radar in the nose radome for storm detection.
components.interactionText: The weather radar detects storms ahead for route deviation decisions.

components.name: APU Exhaust
components.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU in the tail cone.
components.interactionText: The APU provides ground power for the larger aircraft and bleed air for engine starting.

controlSurfaces.name: Ailerons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke turned: fly-by-wire commands aileron deflection modulated by airspeed.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Roll control with envelope protection. The longer fuselage has minimal effect on roll handling.

controlSurfaces.name: Elevator
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke pulled back: elevators up. Pushed forward: elevators down.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Pitch control requires careful rotation technique on the stretched fuselage to avoid tail strikes during takeoff.

controlSurfaces.name: Rudder
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Left pedal: rudder left. Right pedal: rudder right. Speed-dependent authority limiting.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: The longer fuselage moment arm aids directional control but requires awareness of crosswind limitations.

controlSurfaces.name: Trailing Edge Flaps
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Flaps provide critical lift augmentation for the 777-300's high weights on takeoff and landing.

controlSurfaces.name: Leading Edge Slats
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Full-span slats deploy automatically with flap selection.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Slats delay stall for safe low-speed operations at the stretched variant's operating weights.

controlSurfaces.name: Spoilers / Speed Brakes
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Speedbrake lever: symmetric deployment. Roll input: asymmetric deployment.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Speed brakes manage descent rate for the heavier aircraft. Ground spoilers are critical for stopping performance.

controlSurfaces.name: Flaperons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flaperons droop with flap extension and deflect differentially for roll.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Combined flap and aileron function providing both high-lift and roll control.
